t: Why*p do the heathen rage, and the people imagine a vain thing?
The*p kings of the earth set themselves, and the rulers take counsel together, against the Lord,*s and against his anointed, saying,
Let*p us break their bands asunder, and cast away their cords from us.
He*p that sitteth in the heavens shall laugh: the Lord shall have them in derision.
Then*p shall he speak unto them in his wrath, and vex them in his sore displeasure.
Yet*p have I set my king upon my holy hill of Zion.
I*p will declare the decree: the Lord*s hath said unto me, Thou art my Son; this day have I begotten thee.
Ask*p of me, and I shall give thee the heathen for thine inheritance, and the uttermost parts of the earth for thy possession.
Thou*p shalt break them with a rod of iron; thou shalt dash them in pieces like a potter's vessel.
Be*p wise now therefore, O ye kings: be instructed, ye judges of the earth.
Serve*p the Lord*s with fear, and rejoice with trembling.
Kiss*p the Son, lest he be angry, and ye perish from the way, when his wrath is kindled but a little. Blessed are all they that put their trust in him.
